Award.AwardTitle: Nanotechnology REU with a Focus on Community Colleges

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
BROADER SIGNIFICANCE OF THE PROJECT:
The Nanotechnology Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) with a Focus on Community Colleges at Rice University will provide community college students in the Greater Houston area with summer research internships in the field of nanotechnology. The program aims to engage traditionally underrepresented students in the STEM fields by recruiting from community colleges including those that are primarily minority serving institutions. Through laboratory experiences and interactions with faculty, post-docs, and student mentors at Rice University, REU participants will be exposed to STEM research, applications, and careers. Studies show that participation in undergraduate research supports the transition from two-year to four-year colleges and provides a pathway to graduate school and research careers. Students in this program will work on projects that involve real-world applications in the field of energy, medicine, and environmental health. In addition, the program provides considerable training and mentoring of these students not only through the support of the participating Rice faculty, staff, and students but through its strong infrastructure established to promote diversity and student success. A main outcome of the program is to impact students, who otherwise would not have considered STEM research or careers, with enriching and transformative research experiences resulting in a more diverse and expanded STEM workforce.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
The Nanotechnology Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) with a Focus on Community Colleges at Rice University will provide ten community college students in the Greater Houston area with a ten-week summer research internship in the field of nanotechnology. The program aims to impact traditionally underrepresented students in the STEM fields who are represented in significant numbers in the local community colleges. Through laboratory experiences and interactions with faculty, post-docs, and student mentors at Rice University, REU participants will be exposed to STEM research, applications, and careers. Studies show that participation in undergraduate research support the pathway to graduate school and research careers. In addition, the program provides considerable training and mentoring of these students not only through the support of the participating Rice faculty, staff, and students but through its strong infrastructure established to promote diversity and student success. Rice University has made demonstrable strides in the field of nanotechnology with its extensive research facilities, interdisciplinary collaboration, and landmark breakthroughs. This REU program will provide opportunities for students to conduct research involving STEM applications in energy, medicine, and environmental health. Nanotechnology is multidisciplinary, and thus, the research usually brings together many fields of engineering and science. Students will have various research areas for participation that include: synthesis and characterization of new nanomaterials; air and water purification; photonics and plasmonics; medical imaging, diagnoses, and treatment; and clean energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Nanotechnology REU with a Focus on Community Colleges provided a unique opportunity for community college students in the Houston area to participate in summer research in a Rice University laboratory.  During the 3-year award period, the REU program supported 31 interns from 3 local community college systems in 10-week internships. Two REU interns returned as REU cohort mentors for a second year of summer research. The research projects spanned disciplines from nine STEM departments at Rice.  A total of 22 Rice faculty members participated in the REU program by supporting students in their laboratory with research projects and providing 34 post-doctoral or graduate student mentors in all. Postdoctoral and graduate student mentors all participated in mentorship training prior to the start of the summer research.

The REU Program kicked off with a two-day orientation which included laboratory safety training, review of program logistics, luncheon with their mentors, and introductory presentations on nanotechnology. Weekly meetings were held to build a community where REU interns could commune and share their research experiences and REU staff leaders can guide them in their research progress. REU interns kept pace in their preparation of a research abstract and poster for the Smalley-Curl Institute Annual Summer Research Colloquium held at the end of the summer. This capstone event provided an opportunity for them to disseminate their research findings to scientists as well as the broader public. Other program activities included field trips to the Houston Water Works or Schlumberger, a diversity seminar, and training on effective poster presentations.

Evaluation of the program revealed that the REU program provided community college students with valuable insight into the research experience as well as developing tangible laboratory skills. As one REU intern remarked, "I really learned how to work in a grad laboratory. Before I didn't have any idea on how to do it, but I gained a lot of experience and the intense research that goes on the project." Another REU intern added, "I also learned how to handle some more complicated lab equipment that I'd never seen before."  The program was also successful in providing participants with the experience of navigating in a four-year institution. This supported REU students in building their confidence in their own transition to a university.  One student expressed, "I felt a lot more confident, after understanding all of the lab equipment, understanding the experimental process; I began to become a lot, very confident in everything that I did."

The REU program has shown to deliver both direct and indirect impacts. REU interns have contributed to research projects as demonstrated by the poster symposium and through publications and conferences on their REU research. Students have reported that the program has given them confidence to pursue other research endeavors as well as STEM majors at four-year universities where many have transferred to. Others have reported that they have participated in another REU program or research internships in companies. A few REU interns are already employed in STEM professions. Finally, one student currently in medical school remarked, "REU was an amazing program that I was very lucky to be a part of. It kept me motivated in the long path I have chosen in Medicine, despite my modest start as an immigrant starting to pursue my dream in a community college."
